speaker: Mr Speaker
theText: Order! It being 8.00 p.m., 25-1995 No.2.Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 309 Wednesday, 23 August 1995 Australia's Development Cooperation Program Debate resumed from 28 June, on motion by Mr Beazley: That the House take note of the papers. to speak, in the parliament and in the Main Committee. It is interesting that the particular matter we are debating this morning was actually tabled quite a long time ago. The formal report, New directions in Australia's overseas aid program, the ministerial policy paper and the fifth annual report to parliament on Australia's development cooperation program, is dated February 1995, and the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs( Mr Bilney) of course made his statement on 2 March 1995. So we are actually almost six months down the track. My understanding is that a number of things have in fact moved on since this report was tabled and, therefore, we are talking a little about some history but also about a very active area at the present time. It seems to me that this whole area of overseas aid and Australia's development cooperation program is one that could almost have the subtitle of 'It isn't as simple as it seems'. The reason I say that is that most Australians would be kindly disposed towards our overseas aid effort: both the taxpayer funded money that comes from the government and also the money that is collected from the public. When you look at some of the public subscriptions that go on, the vast amounts of money that are pumped into many of those NGOs and the money that is then spent overseas, the Australian public is, by and large, very generous, and there have been a number of issues during the course of this year that have brought these matters very much to newsworthy attention. In spite of that good intention and considerable support, the reality of how you spend that money and where you spend that money-and, in fact, the problems of actually being able to spend that money in the way that one would like to see it do the good that it is intended to do-can often be very difficult indeed. It is perhaps indicative that, even in this relatively slim document, the actual tabled reportwhich is in three sections: 'Recent developments in Australia's aid program', 'New directions in social development in the aid program' and 'New directions in humanitarian relief in the aid program' -covers a very considerable range of activities. It talks about the South Pacific and PNG; about Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos; and about Africa. It also talks about the social sector and cross-sectoral developments, the environment, micro-enterprise development, private sector linkages, refugees and relief programs, the NGO program, volunteers, research, aid effectiveness, policy frameworks and so forth. So it is a very complex area. Minister Bilney, in his speech, probably encapsulated what the government is on about at the moment, and I will talk a bit about some of my views. But I think we need to understand where the government sees itself as going. He encapsulated it when he said in his statement to the House that the government's policy framework for poverty reduction has three major components: firstly, encouragement of sustainable economic growth; secondly, investment in

speaker: Mr Nugent (Aston) (10.00 A.m.)
theText: It is, I must say, nice to be back in the harness, soMC310 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 human resources through education, health, capacity-building and social sector development; and, thirdly, the provision of safety nets and poverty targeting, including humanitarian relief. I do not think there would be too many of us who would argue with those as principles and aims. It is important that we recognise the efforts that Australia does make as a nation, and it is important that there is a degree of continuity between governments and a degree of crossparty support for many of these things. But I do have to chide the government at least gently on one particular matter that is in this report: the statement made in the report that claims that we are now ranked 13th amongst the 22 OECD donors in terms of aggregate aid volume. Our aid currently stands at 0.33 per cent of GNP, substantially better than the 0.3 per cent figure for OECD donors combined, says the report. In his statement the minister also claims that we are one of only four of those 22 nations which spent a bit more money in the last financial year than we did in previous financial years. However, given that most people who take an interest in this sector would like to think that we are moving ever closer to the accepted international target of 0.7 per cent, and we are not even halfway there at the moment, that is a matter for regret. The government prides itself on improving aid substantially and moving in that direction. It has had 12 years in which to achieve that figure. When you measure success against those real targets, it is somewhat disappointing. I am not going to stand here and make some outrageous claim that the coalition, when it wins the next election, is suddenly going to go to 0.7 per cent, but I would certainly hope that we would all work towards getting governments of whichever persuasion to up the amount of money that we contribute. One of the things that has happened to me since this report came out is that I have become much more closely associated with this area. The House will be aware that the minister has set up a advisory committee called COPAC, the Code of Practice Advisory Committee, for non-government organisations-NGOs-particularly for those that operate overseas. This is an area that is often fraught with some difficulty and the recent CARE case has highlighted that difficulty. But there are not only the concerns that were raised by the particular instance of CARE; there has also been an Industry Commission inquiry. The Industry Commission report, although it has not yet been publicised, as I understand it, is likely to raise a number of concerns. The Industry Commission was looking at not only those charities that function overseas, but also charities that work at home. The Industry Commission was looking at the whole question of accountability and accounting and reporting and those sorts of issues. That will involve changing federal legislation and coordinating those changes with the states. The minister has set up this committee and it is charged with providing a code of practice in the short term until the Industry Commission can come up with a more viable longer term process. I do not propose this morning to canvass the issues being considered by that committee or what that committee is likely to find. It is going to report to the minister on 31 August and so it would be inappropriate for me to talk about that committee and its deliberations before that. AllI will say is that I have found the process of taking evidence and working on that committee to be very educative. It seems to me that there are a number of issues to consider. This is why at the start of my comments I made the remark that, when you talk about aid, it is not as simple as it seems. There are a number of issues that come to mind, not least of which is that many governments and private organisations, when they go overseas and try to provide aid to countries in need, Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 311 often encounter this very difficult dichotomy of paternalism versus providing some long-term help, some self-help. They try to set in place sustainable improvements rather than just give handouts and then walk away and find that the mountain falls in straight afterwards. There are simple problems of accounting. What accounting standards do you use? What exchange rates do you use? Do you send your money via some international headquarters? Does it lose value on its way through that headquarters to its final destination? Do you burden aid organisations, particularly the volunteer ones, with onerous administrative and accounting requirements and reporting requirements? Bear in mind that with many of those organisations we are not just talking about government grants; we are talking about organisations that get tax deductibility and, therefore, it is a charge on the taxpayer. Many of those organisations would find that onerous reporting requirements would detract from their direct work. How do you deal with donations in kind? How do you define how much of your budget, in an aid organisation, is going to be spent on administration? What is administration? I am reminded by the Fred Hollows Foundation, for example, that they spend much of their money in this country on research and then, having perhaps in the current financial year spent a large amount of their income on research and developed some new minute lenses, they will set up factories in overseas countries and produce them relatively cheaply in order to put their programs in place on the ground, whereas other organisations may have a far higher proportion of their funds going directly overseas every year. Late last year I had the opportunity, as part of a study tour, of visiting Thailand and Indonesia. World Vision were very good in setting up a number of visits for me whilst I was overseas. I might mention that World Vision moved from their old headquarters in Melbourne to a new headquarters and only made one mistake with their new headquarters-they put it literally on the other side of the road from the boundary of my electorate. If they had been on the other side of the particular road they would have been in my electorate and, of course, that would have been great. Nevertheless, I am sure that the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) is pleased to have them. As I said, with the assistance of World Vision when I went overseas I was able to go and look at not only what they were doing, but also some of the things that the Australian government was doing overseas. For example, in ThailandI travelled up to Chiang Mai in the north, and from Chiang Mai, having visited some hospitals and organisations in the town, I went out into the country, into the hills in northern Thailand where the AIDS problem is absolutely horrendous. I think there are few people in this country who understand that, in places like northern Thailand, the incidence of AIDS is running at about 20 per cent amongst the women-and this is quite young women, as well. Therefore there is a tremendous amount that needs to be done. The Thai government was very slow indeed in coming to grips with this and it is Australian aid that is starting to make some impact on the AIDS issue in Thailand. In Indonesia, one goes to Jakarta and hears from the government about some of the wonderful things the government says it is doing for its country. But, in fact, I went just to the outskirts of Jakarta and saw aid programs where they were installing basic facilities, such as water, in ordinary housing. I went and visited young boys and girls who would not have been going to school if it had not been for Australian aid being pumped into that country. I went up to Bandung in the hills and saw an official Australian aid project helping to sort out MC 312 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 and rationalise the control of the railway system. My concern there, I have to say, was that once Australian expertise was withdrawn I was not too sure how long that system would actually stand up. What worried me, having seen those things in Indonesia, was that I was also taken by my hosts to see the Indonesian aircraft factory where billions of dollars are being spent to produce an aeroplane that is hardly commercial, to be honest. Billions of dollars in high technology and equipment are being spent to try to leapfrog that country into the technological age-and not very successfully-when basics are not being put in place for their own population. Three or four years ago I went to Tonga as part of a delegation to the South Pacific Forum. Again, it seemed to me that, whilst a lot of our aid money was going to buy Mercedes for relatively junior bureaucrats, every primary school I went to did not have a decent waste water or guttering system. While there is a place for humanitarian aid and there is a place for enterprise development, it seems to me that the amount of money and how best we spend that money are, in fact, major problems. There are difficulties of disposal and it seems to me that we have not yet got the process right. Nevertheless, having said that, I think we have to continue to try. As time goes by and we develop better ways of making sure our money actually reaches the target, I am sure we will start to give people back some self-respect and some hope for the future in many of these developing countries. I conclude by saying that earlier this month I was in Malaysia. Malaysia, of course, is a country that no longer takes aid from us and has made giant strides in the last couple of decades. It seems to me that we should be aiming to get many of the countries that we are currently helping to that stage where they can in fact help themselves. pleasure, too, to follow the honourable member for Aston( Mr Nugent), whose continuing interest in this area I have noticed for some years. I compliment him on the work that he has done. He has a genuine concern about poverty in developing countries and about ways of encouraging economic development in developing countries and that is very valuable. I welcome this debate, too, because it arises from a recommendation made by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in a report on overseas aid about six years ago. In that report we proposed not only that this statement be made to parliament every year but that it be debated in parliament. Even though the debate is overdue, it is better that it happen now than not at all. I also welcome the content of the statement itself. I think it is a very valuable statement. I want to speak in two parts: firstly, about the statement itself fairly briefly; and secondly, about the overall context of financial flows to developing countries in trying to broaden out that concept a bit. The first thing to be said about this statement is that it demonstrates how extraordinarily disappointing Australia's aid performance is. That is not to say that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs( Mr Bilney) have not struggled valiantly to increase our aid flows and that their achievement has not been significant. The fact is that, in each of the last two years, Australia's aid budget has increased by about $80 million, and that is a not inconsiderable amount. But it does remain true that our total aid contribution is now 0.33 per cent of our GDP, that the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Langmore (Fraser) (10.15 A.m.)
theText: It is a pleasure to speak in this debate. It is aWednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITIEE MC313 global target for aid is 0.7 per cent and that the average contribution of aid from donor countries-from the 20 donor countries-is in fact 0.46 per cent. This figure is constantly distorted. What happens is that what is presented is a weighted average which weights aid from the United States in relation to its GDP, and Japan in relation to its GDP. It is not a simple arithmetic average. So we get the figure quoted that the weighted average is 0.3, which is true, but that is not a realistic figure. The realistic figure-the proper, accurate figure-is 0.46 per cent and, at 0.33 per cent, Australia is far below that. That means that two-thirds of other countries are providing more aid than Australia as a proportion of their GDP. Some, of course, like Norway, Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands-France evenaverage, but the other three Scandinavian countries, the Netherlands and, in fact, most of the social democratic countries of Europe are providing considerably more than that average. Even Canada, until this year, has been providing about that average 0.45 per cent. So we are constantly given a distorted view. This is not entirely the fault of our own Treasury and the other economic fundamentalists. It is the convention within the DAC, the Development Assistance Committee, of the OECD. It obviously suits the countries that give less, particularly the United States, whose performance is absolutely abominable-down to 0.15 per cent in the most recent figures I have seen. It is disgraceful. A high proportion of funds go to Egypt and Israel. Egypt, of course, does need the funds, but it is a very distorted and politically biased aid program. The performance of the United States is shocking. Japan's has been improving, actually, and is quite useful. Our performance is something we should be ashamed of. That is not to say, by the way, that the opposition, I fear, would do any better. At the last election the opposition was saying that it would cut the aid budget by $200 million, which was an appalling proposal. This is not at all a partisan point I am making. I am making a point about the level of Australian generosity towards people living in absolute poverty. We must remember that a quarter of the global population-I.3 billion people-are living in absolute poverty. That means that at the end of every day they are still hungry, they do not have an adequate place to live, they are inadequately clothed, their lives are disrupted, dislocated, cramped and confined, and their personal potential is not fulfilled because they lack the basic requirements for a good life. We sometimes blame 19th century Britain for the inequities that Dickens demonstrated so vividly in his novels, but we have those inequities writ even larger on our television screens, and yet we do not adequately respond. That is not to say that some people do not respond generously-they do, as the honourable member for Aston said. There is a tradition amongst millions of Australians of contributing generously to voluntary aid programs. Well over $100 million is contributed annually to those programs. One of the interesting features of the statement that we are debating is the report on a survey of public attitudes to development assistance. It reports that the majority of respondents thought the level of Australia's overseas aid should be either increased or maintained at current levels. That is an encouraging reflection of community attitudes. However, I emphasise that our own performance is something about which we should be ashamed and that we are not, in any sense, responding to the intensity of the need.

theText: Finland, thank you. Actually, Finland is 0.45, so it is about on theMC 314 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 Having made that point as strongly as I can, I now go on to the orientation of this statement. I think the orientation is excellent. It is a very valuable statement. It demonstrates a thoughtful approach to the uses of our aid and to the regional destinations of our aid. It talks particularly, for example, about the South Pacific region and Papua New Guinea, Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos, where there is great poverty, and about Africa, which is the greatest centre of poverty in the world. Then it talks about the particular areas to which aid will be given. The report also has a very good section on social development. I particularly draw attention in that to the way in which the present minister has upgraded the population program. Probably the most cost effective form of aid is support for population programs. If the rate of population growth is even marginally reduced, then the possibility of increasing per capita incomes, of investing more productively, of increasing productivity in agriculture and industry, is significantly increased. A real inadequacy in our aid program for a long time was that we gave so little to population programs. The present minister and the previous minister have redressed that, and there is now a whole series of very valuable programs that we are supporting in countries that want themIndonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam, Papua New Guinea, China and countries in the South Pacific. I think that this development of the aid program is one that deserves the wholehearted support of all Australians. There has been some controversy about the nature of one or two of those programs and it is very important, of course, that population programs be voluntary, that they be educative and that they aim to provide family planning information and capacity to people who want it, but that people not be forced to accept it. That is very important, obviously. But, given that proviso, this is one of the most cost effective forms of aid that we can offer and it is very valuable that it is being increased. There are also good sections on health and education, both of which are profoundly important in development programs. In fact, to oversimplify only a little, one could say that investment in education is perhaps the best indicator of determination to achieve greater economic and social development, because it increases people's skills, it increases their capacity to help themselves and it is the basis for many other forms of change that are essential if economic development is going to be strongly sustained. It is very good that we are building up our commitment there. I think this section was in the report because it was prepared just before the world summit for social development. That summit was concentrating on ways of reducing poverty, unemployment and social disintegration. Australia made a very valuable contribution to the preparation for the summit and this report was part of that. I want to move on now to briefly talk about the wider issue of the total resource flow to developing countries. There has been a tendency to be rather traditional in our approach to development and to see development assistance simply in terms of aid, but of course what matters to developing countries is the total level of resources they receive, from all sources. That includes not only concessional financing but also private investment, trade credits and lending to governments. All of those forms of resource flows are of value to developing countries in the development process. There is quite a good table in the budget paper on overseas aid programs which draws together all the resource flows to developing countries. It shows that in total resources flows in the 1990s have been rising, particularly because there has been an increase in private investment. However, total resource flows are still well below what they were the beginning VVednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 315 of the 1980s. It is that figure which perhaps most clearly demonstrates the problems that many developing countries have in achieving the resources they need in order to expand their investment. I think it is very important that we not only look at total resource flows as the best indicator of international development cooperation but see what has been happening to those total resource flows. VVhen we do that, we find not only that they have been rising recently and that they are lower than they were 15 years ago, but also that they are concentrated in a few developing countries. This is another source of worry. The principal recipients of total flows are China, Mexico, Argentina, Thailand and the Republic of Korea. In fact, in 1993 and 1994 China received most of the net increase in resource flows. China is a quarter of humankind, so that is not entirely surprising, but it has been very fashionable for private investment to flow to China in the last few years. That is important but it demonstrates gaping holes in total resource flows to countries which need it most. However, there has been some response to that situation of concessional public sector aid flows and now an increasing share of total resource flows is going to the sub-Sahara in Africa and other really impoverished countries. The response of the aid agencies in many countries has been to increase the flows to the poor countries. I see my time is just about up. I have a lot more to say but I will use another occasion to do so. contribution. I am pleased to follow my colleague the honourable member for Fraser( Mr Langmore), whose contribution-and, indeed, whose commitment-to this subject is so well known. VVhat he says is always interesting, but I was particularly interested in his comments about the United States because it just so happens that last week I was in the United States-in VV ashington-and I met with some of the congressional people there. VVhat came across to me, with this new Congress they have in the United States, is just how isolationist they are becoming. looking into Africa and I spoke with the equivalent committee in the United States. First of all, they said they had great difficulty getting anyone to serve on that committee; and, secondly, they said to me-and they made no apology for it and said it most unashamedly'There are no votes for us in Africa, there are no votes for us in aid, and what we are trying to do is deal purely with the local issues.' VVhenI raised the question of the position of the United States in the world, they did not laugh at me, but they looked at me if I was a very naive person from some other part of the world. They were making the point that, in Congress, they have elections every two years and they are not going to worry too much about what is happening in Africa and other parts of the world. They were going to very much worry about what was happening in their own particular bailiwick. I left that meeting, and VVashington, very disappointed. There has always been a tendency in the United States to become isolationist, but that tendency is very strong today and it is a bit frightening. It is disappointing that they do not see that they have a very important role in the whole question of aid.

speaker: Mr Nugent
theText: It's getting worse.

speaker: Mr Hollis
theText: Yes, it is getting worse. As people know, I chair a committee here that isMC 316 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 I took note of what the member for Fraser said in the criticisms he offered, but I also agree with him that the paper we are debating is a very welcome and well-focused paper. We cannot correct all the wrongs of the world and there is never enough money to do everything we would like to do. But it is important that our aid is focused: we must not have a broad-brush approach but a very focused approach to our whole aid question. I naturally also very much support the comments he made on the population issues. Like all members of parliament I am often challenged on the aid question. One group in the community argues that Australia does not give enough overseas aid and claims that what it does give is poorly channelled. Another group points out the real or imagined economic problems we have in this country and suggests that, really, charity begins at home. Some would say that there should be no government aid at all and that all aid should be raised through the private sector. I suppose that, as in all things, government action is a matter of competing interests, but I believe that this government has made a significant contribution to poverty alleviation through the Australian aid program. Of course, those who argue that Australia should give no overseas aid overlook the fact that much of this money is spent in Australia, or by employing Australians on overseas aid projects. I know the linking of aid to trade is a contentious issue. Nevertheless, it is an issue of considerable economic significance to many Australians. In this parliament last week there was a seminar organised by Community Aid Abroad and World Vision. This whole question of tying trade to aid was raised there and I thought it was dealt with in a very sensible and understanding way. The honourable member for Aston( Mr Nugent), in his contribution, said that the question of aid is not as easy as it seems; and that is true. But I must say that I have visited many Australian overseas aid projects and I have always found them to be well run and of great benefit where they are. I guess, Mr Deputy Speaker, that when the question of aid is raised with you by your constituents-as it is with me-the Mekong Friendship Bridge is always mentioned. I actually doubt that any other issue has generated as much misinformation as the Mekong Friendship Bridge has. Last year, as part of a parliamentary delegation, I was privileged to cross this bridge, which is one of the most visible examples of the effectiveness of Australia's development assistance. It is the first road link between Laos and Thailand, and will yield significant economic benefits to both countries. Indeed, if anyone needed proof of this, they need only look at the entrepreneurial activities which have already commenced on the Thai side. On the Laos side, there will actually have to be something done about the road. It is not particularly the best road-it is not the federal highway that we are used to-when you try and travel from the bridge into the capital. Nevertheless, it has been of tremendous importance to those two countries. As important as the bridge is for the economies of Laos and Thailand, it is one of the highest profile aid projects undertaken by Australia in recent years-and, incidentally, it was completed under time and under budget. The bridge is a showcase of what Australian excellence in technology design and infrastructure transfer can achieve, and of what Australia can deliver; as such, it is very important in our expanding trade relationship with Asia. Population issues have continued to be an important aspect of Australia's overseas aid program. As one who is convinced that overpopulation and economic underdevelopment are closely linked, I welcome the emphasis in our aid program on population issues. The priority Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 317 which the aid program affords population issues was reflected in the major role that Australia played at the International Conference on Population and Development held in Cairo in December of last year. Australia was active in encouraging the international conference to adopt the groundbreaking program of action for the empowerment of women, and called for major increases in global resources for family planning and health services. I would also like to refer to the significant developments in the nature of our assistance to the health sector. Funding for health was given a major boost in the 1994-95 aid budget, with the introduction of a four-year initiative targeting four priority areas: malaria, polio, tetanus and HIV/AIDS. The innovation involves additional funding of $110 million over four years, nearly doubling Australia's current spending on health under the aid program. As with assistance for population activities, AusAID has developed a set of principles which will guide this new funding. These principles state that improvements in health are best achieved through an integrated approach which tackles the causes of poverty and improves the status and well-being of vulnerable groups, particularly women and children. Changes are also under way in Australia's program of assistance to education and training. Australia has recently refined its aid program to Africa, under a statement entitled 'New framework for Australia's aid to Africa', made on 16 August-only last week-by the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs( Mr Bilney). It is important. Australia still makes a significant contribution of aid to Africa-something like a $190 million-but that aid is going to be very much targeted to Zimbabwe, South Africa and Mozambique, and I have a few worries about the targeting. AlthoughI welcome the specific targeting of aid, one worry I have is that, with South Africa being flavour of the month, as it were, at the moment, all of the money not only from Australia but from many other parts of the world-be it from the European Community or other areasis going to flow into South Africa. That is good for South Africa and I think it is good that we are making a contribution. We are not the largest aid giver to South Africa but the money that we are giving should, I believe, be targeted to short training courses which bring people to Australia for, say, nursing or teacher training. We do not want to be funding any more PhDs. My worry about South Africa is that all the countries are putting money into South Africaand that is fine-but, unless the countries surrounding South Africa can deal with their problems, whatever we do in South Africa is going to come to nought. For example, unless the economies of Mozambique and Angola come right, refugees will cross the border in their millions. As poor as parts of South Africa are at the moment, it is still much better off than the surrounding countries. Already there are a couple of million people crossing the border each year. If the aid that people are giving is all going to South Africa-and, for sure, South Africa has the economic structure and is the economic power of that region-that country will be a magnet for those poor people all around it. Unless we can get their economies right and persuade them not to seek the higher economic advantage of going to South Africa, all the work we are doing in South Africa will not be for nought but will become much more difficult. I think we should look a bit broader. We cannot tackle all the problems of Africa, of course we cannot. Instead of just focusing on Mozambique, Zimbabwe and South Africa-and it is important that we focus on these three countries-perhaps we could spread the net a little wider and help, say, the 11 SADC countries to get their economies right. If we provided some MC 318 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 economic aid for those countries, perhaps many of the problems coming up in South Africa will not need to be addressed. One of the real issues for South Africa is people crossing the borders all the time from surrounding countries. In conclusion, I would like to commend the government for the courage it has taken over the last few years in increasing the funding on the population issue. I know it has not been easy and I know there has been criticism raised about it. I know also that there has been a lot of nonsense spoken about it and that a lot of misinformation has been peddled out in the community. Those who argue against funding for population issues have to justify why they are arguing to keep women and children in a situation of absolute poverty and in life threatening conditions. I think there is a link between underdevelopment and overpopulation. Anyone who has been to any of those countries would have seen the sorts of conditions that people are subjected to in the way they have to live. I think every child born should be a wanted child and that every child born should have the opportunity to reach its full potential, whatever that potential may be. While we continue, for religious, moral or social grounds, to deny these people this attitude, we are subjecting people to a life that we would not particularly want to live. I have always been amazed by the line the Catholic church takes on population issues. It also surprises me that ageing clerics run around in drag, dictating how women should control their own fertility. The people who should be able to decide how they control their own fertility are the women themselves, but they should have the education, the opportunity and the means to do so. Mr Barry Jones-No role for cross-dressing. telling women how they should control their own fertility. It is an outrage and it is an outrage that we should tolerate no longer. I welcome this discussion paper on Australia's development cooperation program and I commend the minister for it. I also welcome the decision to have such a paper for debate each year and I hope that this paper is the first of many papers on these topics. about Australia's development cooperation program provides members of the parliament with an opportunity to canvass some of the particular issues about our aid program and the extent to which Australia fulfils its responsibilities. To follow people like the member for Aston( Mr Nugent), the member for Fraser( Mr Langmore) and the member for Throsby( Mr Hollis) and to precede people like the member for Melbourne ( Mr Tanner), who will, presumably, follow me in this discussion, is something of an honour because all these people have shown by their earlier actions and by their continuing concern the depth of their feelings about a lot of the issues that are involved here. I take this opportunity to acknowledge the presence in the public gallery of one of our former colleagues, Mrs Elaine Darling. Mrs Darling was the very highly regarded, very well respected and very much liked member for Lilley and she was among us for a period of 13 years. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, Mrs Darling was the first woman member of the House of Representatives to represent any constituency in Queensland. It is particularly appropriate that Elaine is here at the present time because Elaine is one of these people who have a passionate concern about social equity not only in Australia but throughout the world.

theText: This motion to take note of the paperWednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITIEE MC 319 The effectiveness, the force and the presentation of the submissions that she made to this parliament and, through this parliament to the national community, will stand as a continuing tribute to her effectiveness and her commitment. A record of her effectiveness and commitment is contained in the continuing historic record which the Hansard records of debates for the parliament provide and will continue to provide into the future. I welcome Mrs Elaine Darling. Mrs Darling is the sort of person who should always-and will-be welcome in this institution. The Australian aid program is an expression of a number of things about the way in which the Australian community relates to general questions about aid and its international responsibilities. We have sought to secure a balance between a number of the elements which could be expected to influence our attitude. First of all there is our humanitarian concern, particularly in the context of the admirable comment which was made by my colleague, the member for Fraser. The Australian aid program is also recognition of the fact that Australiaparticularly in terms of our resource endowment, our level of development, our institutional stability and our per capita income-is one of the most privileged countries in the world. The program reflects Australia's growing recognition of the fact that the world must be seen as a global community. Some people refer to the world as the global village within whichMr Barry Jones-Marshall McLuhan's term. because it is so apt. Within that global community and within that global village, all countries have a responsibility to others. There is also the matter of Australia's acceptance of our special responsibility towards Papua New Guinea, the South Pacific, South-East Asia and, increasingly, the countries in the Indian Ocean area. I refer particularly to the question of the nature of the global village because I am reminded that my maternal great-grandparents and my paternal great-great-grandparents came out from England, Wales and Ireland in the middle of the last century. The fastest time in which my ancestors could get to Australia was three months. I can now get to England, Wales or Ireland in 24 hours. In effect, as a result of that technological development, the speed of travel, the bringing together of communities around the world, we have physically contracted the globe from the size that it was in the middle of the last century to something which is now one-ninetieth the size, because what took us 90 days before now takes us one day. So those people who, at one time, we thought were around the other side of the world are not. They are next door; they are 24 hours away. Within that distance of 24 hours travel, there is abject massive poverty. And they are neighbours; they are like the people next door. We would not tolerate starvation of Australians in Victoria, Western Australia or the Northern Territory. We are prepared to tolerate it elsewhere. My friend and colleague John Langmore said that we should be ashamed of our effort. What we are providing this year is 0.33 per cent of GOP. The UN target is 0.7 per cent. We are about 13th among 24 countries of the OECD in terms of the contribution that we make to international aid. Last year our increase was 3.6 per cent, which was less than our GOP. John Langmore said that we should be ashamed. I think so too. He also made the point that one-quarter of the world's people live in abject poverty-that is 1.3 billion people. Those 1.3 billion people are not just under difficult circumstances; they are in abject poverty. Once before, I made an observation, and let me repeat it so that we put this into context. I made the observation that every three to four seconds one child dies as a result of preventable
title: Representatives Main Commjttee

speaker: Mr Robert Brown
theText: Exactly! A very apt term and one which has been widely adoptedMC 320 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 malnutrition and disease. That is 1,200 every hour; that is 30,000 kids every day; that is II million kids every year. Preventable diseases and preventable malnutrition! Let me put that into some further context. Every year the world spends money on what we like to call military expenditure. You can call it whatever you like. You can call it defence. In some cases, quite clearly, it is preparation for war, though not on our part. Unfortunately, there are still aggressive nations in the world, as we know, so that is part of it as well. Every year the world spends on military expenditure one million million dollars-$I trillion. What a reflection that is on the morality of the world. At Copenhagen earlier this year, at the World Summit for Social Development, a paper was issued-John Langmore provided me with my copy-which drew attention to that fact. It also drew attention to the fact that, by taking one-quarter of that $1 trillion-by taking $250 billion or $250,000 million-out of that total military preparation budget, the world could eliminate those critical problems which cause massive suffering and all of those deaths. For example, the world could eliminate starvation and malnourishment with $19 billion; health care could be covered with $15 billion; shelter, for the people who do not have shelter, could be provided with $21 billion; safe, clean water-something that we take for grantedcould be provided with $50 billion. We could retire the Third World debt with $30 billion. We could prevent soil erosion with $24 billion. With $10 billion, we could stabilise popUlation, a matter that was referred to quite correctly-let us make no mistake-by my colleague Colin Hollis. We could have clean, safe, efficient and renewable energy with $50 billion. With one-quarter of the total military budget we could overcome those problems of the world-and we do not do it! So when John Langmore correctly says, 'We should be ashamed,' I say, 'Yes, we shouldeveryone of us.' I repeat: every one of us. Let no-one try to excuse himself or herself from the fact that they are single members of the world community which allows that situation to prevail. Let no-one claim innocence. I said that with $250 billion we could overcome those problems. That is only about half of Australia's gross domestic product each year, and we are just a little country in the world. Half of our GDP each year would overcome all of those problems throughout the world-and the world fails to act adequately. This report, New directions in Australia's overseas aid program, is the fifth annual report. Last year's report concentrated particularly on Australia's approach to reducing poverty. This year's report builds on that and deals in particular with our approach to social development and humanitarian relief, and of course the details are adequately canvassed in the report. I applaud, endorse and support the attempts that people make, including, let me say, those of the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs( Mr Bilney), in whose name the report was issued. Gordon Bilney has a proud background and record in connection with questions of this kind. He is a well-chosen minister in that portfolio and I know that he, as well as so many of my colleagues, is doing what he can in connection with this. There are certain historic reasons as well, I should say, why Australia should pay so much attention to Papua New Guinea. I think about 22 per cent of our total aid program goes to Papua New Guinea. The responsibility of assisting there means that the program is then reduced for other countries in the world that we may be able to assist, but we do have those historical responsibilities and that is quite appropriate. I would like to see the aid program increased. It did increase in real terms by, I think, 3.6 per cent last year. We were one of the very few countries that increased our aid program last year in real terms, so some effort is Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 321 being made. But, while ever the reality of those circumstances that I just described prevails, we are not moving fast enough, we are not doing enough, and it reflects on every single one of us. address the question of the ministerial statement and the accompanying booklet, New directions in Australia's overseas aid program, that was tabled not so long ago by the minister. I would also like to take the opportunity of making a few remarks on the broader question of Australia's aid budget and the direction of our policy with respect to overseas aid. I do have a number of observations that I would like to make in that regard and, from memory, this is the first opportunity that I have had in the parliament to make some comments on the question of our aid program. I will start by pointing out that, certainly in my electorate, overseas aid is a fairly major issue. My electorate is not necessarily a typical electorate in many respects, but I do believe that this issue is an important one right across the community. In my electorate I am contacted, virtually on a weekly basis, by constituents, church groups, and local aid organisations about a whole variety of issues associated with Australia's aid program. There can be no doubt that there are a lot of Australians who are active in aid groups, people who donate to the many worthwhile projects that the aid groups participate in, and people who are very concerned about Australia's overseas aid program. Those people have some strong views about how we should be pursuing our assistance to countries-particularly in our region, but also generally. Often politicians tend to understate the importance of aid. Like rabbits out of a hat, they pull out statements like 'charity begins at home', without realising that for a lot of people this issue is important, even in a fairly narrow sense. I will tum quickly to the aid budget for this year, which has been mentioned by previous speakers. I think it is worth placing on the record my views about this budget. This year's aid budget was increased by $83 million. In real terms, the increase was effectively worth about $28 million, so the total budget is now up to $1,563 million or thereabouts. In context, that was a reasonably good result. SinceI have been here, I have been part of the debates in the pre-budget period about the aid budget, trying to make sure that it is increased-and also at the ALP national conference last year, where similar issues were dealt with. As has been noted by the honourable member for Fraser( Mr Langmore), one of the unfortunate aspects of this year's aid budget is that it has again reduced our total aid contribution-not to a historically low level, but certainly to one of the lowest levels for some considerable period of time-down to 0.33 per cent of gross domestic product. It is fair to say that this decrease will make it fairly difficult for us to achieve our official policy target of 0.4 per cent by the year 2000 and 0.5 per cent by 2005. On the face of it, this is a grim statistic and something that we ought to be taking some stock of. It is true to say that Australia is above average relative to the OECD with respect to aid-although, as the honourable member for Fraser indicated in his contribution, there are some doubts about the methodology of assessing that average-but I do not think in an area like this we are entitled to consider that that performance is good enough. So, in my view, it is fundamentally important that we improve our performance in terms of our overseas aid contribution. It is worthwhile pointing out though, as something of an alibi, that it is slightly artificial to be critical of the government for failing to increase the overseas aid budget sufficiently in
title: Representatives Main Commitiee

speaker: Mr Tanner (Melbourne) (10.59 A.m.)
theText: I am very pleased to have the opportunity toMC 322 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 a time when growth rates are running at a very high level. The countervailing proposition is that when we are in recession it is okay to reduce the overseas aid budget, or not to worry about trying to increase it, because the base against which you are measuring it is not growing, or in fact may well be contracting. So an alibi, with respect to criticisms of the government, is that one of the reasons why we have seen a drop is that the gross domestic product has been growing over the last year or two at a very high rate. Turning to a couple of specific aspects of the aid budget, I was pleased to see that aid to Africa has been increased by 21 per cent, up to over $122 million. This is an area that we have historically neglected. It is also good to see that aid to south Asia has been increased to $74 million, although it is a bit distressing to see that both of these increases are substantially explained in terms of, in a sense, catching up on last year's promised increase. It is also worth pointing out that some of the increases can be explained by program increases that are, in my view, of limited value. For example, assistance to the coal industry in India, which is designed to increase the efficiency of the coal industry there, is unlikely to have any great benefits for the vast bulk of the poorer people in India. However, it is worth noting that there are quite a number of important new initiatives or improved initiatives in the aid budget. There is an extra $25 million to cover basic technical and further education programs in Bangladesh, Mongolia, Gaza, the Philippines, South Africa and the Pacific. It is also worth noting the funding to the International Crisis Group and the Institute of Democracy and Electoral Assistance. There has been a doubling in funding for the Women in Development Fund. The increases to expenditure on women's education and child labour issues are also worthy of note. However, there are one or two disturbing aspects. For example, $6.8 million is to go to the Korean Energy Development Organisation, which is part of the process of supposedly defusing nuclear tension on the Korean Peninsula. In reality, it involves us in developing the nuclear industry in Korea and that is something that I have some trouble with. I am also pleased to see that the DIFF program has been reduced by $10 million, from $130 million to $120 million. That is because that is essentially driven by commercial objectives rather than by aid objectives. The fact that virtually everybody else does it is not a sufficient argument to justify Australia saying that our aid program is basically a self-interest exercise designed to deliver commercial benefits to Australians. I think it is worth remembering that the Jackson committee report in 1994 recommended that our aid strategy should be based on poverty alleviation and humanitarian objectives as the primary focus, and that diplomatic and commercial objectives should be subsidiary to that. It is certainly questionable as to whether we have achieved that objective. It is concerning that, particularly in that light, Au sAID still seems to harbour economic growth as the primary factor in poverty alleviation, hence the assistance to the Indian coal industry. It states in AusAID's poverty policy that 'sustainable economic growth is an essential pre-requisite for poverty reduction' . There is a sense in which equity issues and distribution issues are seen as, in some way, being secondary. Not far below the surface we have the infamous trickle-down analysis, and the notion that if the economic circumstances of the wealthier elites of a country are improved that will inevitably drag everybody else in the country up with them. In fact, the evidence and experience suggests that the reverse occurs-that there is growing inequality, that there is Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 323 growing disruption in communities, and that there are serious adverse impacts from major projects and the like. I am not being strongly critical of AusAID in this regard, because I believe that this situation is changing. It is changing in the wake of changes with international institutions such as the World Bank. The 1990 World Development Report of the World Bank states: Rapid and politically sustainable progress on poverty has been achieved by pursuing a strategy that has two equally important elements. The first element is to promote the productive use of the poor's most abundant asset, labour. It calls for policies that harness marketing incentives, social and political institutions, infrastructure and technology to that end. The second is to provide basic social services to the poor. Primary health care, family planning, nutrition and primary education are especially important In my view that is something approximating a reasonable balance in an aid philosophynamely, that equity issues are at least as important as growth issues. It seems to me that, at least until recently, we have been somewhat lagging behind on that particular issue. In 1993 the World Bank said that government intervention appeared in some instances to have resulted in higher and more equal growth than otherwise would have occurred. It is also particularly clear that strategies of aid based on market libera1isation tend to have serious adverse consequences-for example, particularly adverse consequences on women in rural and tribal communities. A recent study for the Asian Development Bank entitled Rural poverty in Asia confirmed those conclusions. There are signs that our policy is shifting to a greater emphasis on human capital, on assisting people with things like family planning, basic health care and education as a greater priority. For example, it is very pleasing to see that in recent times the proportion of our education aid budget that goes to tertiary education has significantly declined and there is an increasing shift in emphasis towards primary and basic education and technical education, which is obviously where it ought to be. I would think that, although there is some value in providing assistance through the mechanisms of tertiary education, that is predominantly going to assist entrenched elites in the countries where the assistance is provided and the direct impact on people in poverty in those countries will be very, very limited. However, the impact of broadening the provision of basic education in those countries can be of considerable value. SoI think that in some respects, to be fair to the minister and to AusAID, the emphasis is changing for the better. Certainly the statement that we are giving consideration to today is a good indication that that shift is under way. I would like to see it go further, to ensure that the emphasis is very strongly on the question of poverty alleviation and social justice and that questions of equality, equity and access to basic health and education services have primacy in our strategy. The next comment I would like to make is on a matter that was addressed by my colleague the member for Throsby( Mr Hollis) which I have very strong views on, as he does. That is the question of population control and family planning programs. In the 1993-94 budget we went through a bit of a fiasco where, to satisfy the rather peculiar views of one independent senator, we had to put on hold a very substantial increase in the population and development programs in the aid budget. Thankfully, the study that was undertaken as part of that agreement did confirm the clear connections between population growth rates and levels of underdevelopment, poverty and the like. It is good to see this in the minister's statement to the House in March this year: Access to safe and effective family planning services is a fundamental right. MC 324 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 It is long overdue that religious fundamentalism is removed from these debates and that Australia pursues strategies with respect to family planning assistance to poorer countries that are based on the practical realities of life and not on religious zealotry. I certainly would share the views of the honourable member for Throsby that any attempt to disrupt our aid program or to disrupt population strategies and assistance in that regard should be condemned. The final comment I would make in the one minute that remains to me is to endorse the remark made by the member for Charlton( Mr Robert Brown) towards the end of his contribution that these issues are, as a result of internationalisation, rapidly going to become domestic issues. The notion that charity begins at home is, in my view, valid in the sense that the earth is our home, and so I see Australians and Australia as having just as much interest, both in a practical and a theoretical sense, in the lives, futures and circumstances of people overseas, particularly in our region, as they do in problems that we face here in this country. We will have to confront these issues more and more as practical problems that we have to deal with domestically. Because of internationalisation, they are not things over there; they are things that are going to confront us here and now as issues that do affect us, and that is something that will, hopefully, inform increases in our aid program in the future. Debate (on motion by Mr Hawker) adjourned. Justice Statement Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Mr Beazley: That the House take note of the paper. the contribution of many eminent people in the production and development of the Justice Statement. The ability to access justice is an issue that goes out to touch many people in our community, and that is particularly so for women, whom I represent in my portfolio responsibilities as shadow minister for the status of women. The Justice Statement is, undoubtedly, the result of the dedication and effort of some very highly qualified people, and that is certainly evident, as you read through this report, in the quality of the recommendations presented. A feature of this government has been its eagerness to undertake and commission studies, reviews, committees and so forth. In fact, one cannot fault the data collection process, and it has usually been done by the best available people. But the government's commitment to implementing and progressing the recommendations made so often falls on infertile ground. It certainly does not match the commitment of the review process, and that has to be of concern to everyone, as well. The government continually stalls in its implementation of inquiry recommendations. We see this across many portfolios, and it is very evident in my other shadow portfolio of small business, with too many reports being left to gather dust on ministers' desks or on the many bookshelves in this place. The Justice Statement is yet another example of the government's regurgitation of existing policies. They have a wonderful statement here but, in terms of translating this Justice Statement into actual policy, they are short on. What we have actually seen is a regurgitation, in some areas-not new initiatives, and not always the implementation of the recommendations that have been made. So, under the guise of a new cover, and with the pretence that the community will not notice such a sleight of hand, we get the outcome of that report, and it
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mrs Moylan (Pearce) (11.15 A.m.)
theText: It is important from the outset that we acknowledgeWednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITIEE MC 325 is not entirely in keeping with all of the commitment and recommendations that have been made. Existing programs in some instances have been operating for a period of time already, before this report came out. Sometimes there is a bit of tinkering at the edges but no substantive move to change, but the programs have been conveniently repackaged to provide the perception that the government is initiating new policies. This is alluded to in the foreword of the Justice Statement, which states: The Government now responds to the challenge for change in our legal system with this Statement. That statement has to be analysed, and I will comment on a number of aspects of the Justice Statement as they relate to women and small business. PerhapsI will take a look at two or three of the positives first. There has been, of course, some commitment to increasing the funding in order to fund some of the recommendations made by the task force. For example, provision will be made of $12.3 million over four years to establish a national network of women's legal centres, to provide advice and assistance to those women in city and country areas who have legal problems. The government will provide an additional $5 million over four years to enable the network of women's legal centres to establish specialist services for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women, and those shifts are welcomed by the coalition. The government will commit an extra $500,000 to establish a national outreach and development fund to develop legal information resources on issues relevant to women, including family law matters, violence against women, discrimination, employment matters, 'sexually transmitted debt' I am not sure what that last one means-and other areas of law. So there are some moves by the government to increase funding levels in relation to the delivery of justice. The government's commitment to justice for women, though, must be considered objectively against its other funding priorities. The Justice Statement is forecast to receive nearly $39 million in 1995-96. Of these funds, approximately $26.48 million has been allocated to issues closely associated with women and their families. So, out of that total funding, about $26 million will go specifically to women and to their families. Approximately $6.6 million has been specifically allocated to justice issues of immediate concern to women. On a per capita basis, this represents an outlay of $1 per woman aged 15 years and over in Australia. By contrast, the Australian Trade Union Training Authority will receive $8.7 million from the 1995-96 federal budget for its activities, a per capita rate of approximately $1. On balance, this reflects the government's priority to look after its mates ahead of the interests of women. One dollar a year is unlikely to provide any meaningful solution to the access and equity difficulties confronting many Australian women in their dealings with Australia's justice system. The services of a solicitor today could cost between $100 and $250 per hour while the cost of the services of a QC begins at a low of about $2,000 but can go very quickly upward depending on the complexity and the nature of the issue being addressed. There are many in the community who simply do not qualify for legal aid and who have no recourse to justice in this country. That is particularly so for many thousands of women. A further feature of the Justice Statement is the deceptive nature of many of the sUbprograms. Take, for example, the expenditure allocated to domestic violence. The budget reduced the community education violence against women program in Budget Paper No. 1 and announced the cessation of the program which was delivered by the Office of the Status MC 326 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 of Women. The saving for the government is $1.15 million. This is particularly interesting in view of the fact that yesterday the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Dr Lawrence), in a big media scene, announced that the government had now completed, through the Office of the Status of Women, a research paper on community attitudes to violence against women. I have no criticism of this report at all and it reveals some very interesting points. For example, it reveals that community attitudes toward violence against women have shifted very dramatically. A large number of people believe now that violence against women in domestic situations is a crime and that violence is no longer an acceptable way for people to deal with disputes within the family home. But it is curious: the minister said that this education program to produce a shift in results is a very important part of the process of dealing with domestic violence; when a survey was done in 1975, the results clearly showed that most people thought that domestic violence and disputes in domestic situations were only the business of the people involved in the dispute. Most people thought that the police should not have any jurisdiction in such situations and that domestic violence should not be considered to be a crime. Clearly, community views have changed and there is no doubt that part of the shift in attitude about this matter is because of the allocation of funds to the community education program through the Office of the Status of Women. What do we see? We see a program that is working and that is producing a result and yet the government has swiped the funding out from under its feet. The government is saying that it is not going to fund that program any more and that the program will cease to exist. I do not believe-despite the big shift in community attitudes-that we can afford to let go of this. We need to continue with a community education program to make sure that people understand that domestic violence is not an option. At the end of the last sitting, the minister declared that the government was going to spend another $1.1 million on yet another data collecting process on domestic violence. What we see here is a policy vacuum created by the government: an inability to translate its data collection process into policy and an inability to deliver outcomes to the electorate, in many cases. It is one thing to change community attitudes, but we have seen an increase in the incidence of violence against women in their own homes. Clearly, the next step for the government is to take measures to change the behaviour of people in our community in terms of their use of violence as an option to resolve disputes. We are not seeing that agenda moved forward. We are not seeing that agenda move forward. It is one thing to change the attitudes and it is another to change the behaviour. What we are seeing, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, is an increase in the incidence of domestic violence in Australia today, and it is quite a substantial increase. The national crime statistics, for example, reveal that the number of sexual assaults for the 12 months ending December 1994 has increased by eight per cent or 515 additional assaults. In total, 13,277 individuals reported being sexually assaulted during this period. That is 37 sexual assaults per day. Clearly, it is going to take more than an education program to get these behaviour changes. It is going to take more than setting up centres for people to go to find out what their rights are and get some access to justice, and there will still be many women who simply will not have that option. If they do not qualify for legal aid they are unlikely to obtain justice in this Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 327 area. What we have to do is start changing the behaviour. That is a critical part of the move to deal with this problem in the community. One must question the efficacy of disbanding a policy that was clearly delivering some outcomes. But this program will be replaced largely by a network of women's legal centres, including five centres to be newly established and others with their roles expanded. Some of those centres are already in operation in the capital cities. This was hailed as a new initiative but, in fact, it is an old one that is just being expanded. There is no criticism of the expansion. There is a gap in the provision of services to women. The Justice Statement states that, over the next few months, the government will consult with local communities to determine the best locations for the new services and the most appropriate options for delivering services to meet the needs of each region. In other words, services and support for women will decline while the government procrastinates, yet again, over the next move. After 13 years in government, with a high focus on this particular area, they still now have to proceed with a process that may take several months to complete before this process of expanding the legal centres happens. There is a gap here which would cause a great deal of concern and more delays in the provision of vital services. It would be reasonable to expect that the process of identifying the need for the initiatives outlined in the Justice Statement would also have been suitable for the development of models for the identification and establishment of delivery mechanisms to ensure immediate implementation of services to women. After all, many-if not all-of these issues have been the subject of numerous studies, reports, consultancies and commissions over the last 13 years. What we have in here is all the recommendations but no plan as to how to implement these recommendations. Now we will go through another gap period before the implementation of those recommendations that are going to be implemented occurs. BeforeI wind up, I would also like to touch briefly on small business. The small business sector does not gain much new benefit from the Justice Statement, as almost all of the initiatives outlined in the report are already established. The commitment of an extra $1.7 million over four years to expand the corporate law simplification program is welcome, but is unlikely to generate the much needed focus required to accelerate the pace of the reform process. Small businesses are still being overwhelmed by the proliferation and complexity of corporations law, as well as taxation and trade practices law. In fact, if one looks at a list of items that are constantly raised within the small business arena, one sees that issues such as legislation affecting competition, copyright law, parliamentary consultation, the drafting of legislation, the simplification of corporations law, the rewriting of the taxation act into plain English, the review of outdated legislation, business regulation, consumer protection, delegated legislation, trade practices and the Freedom of Information Act are just some of the many issues that are impacting severely on small business today. We have to get beyond delivering the reports and deliver the outcomes.
