title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Tanner (Melbourne) (11.30 A.m.)
theText: There is a slight sense of deja vu in making aMC 328 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 Justice Statement. In fact, it was October of last year that we were debating the proposals in the Sackville report in the Main Committee. Just to recap on the propositions that the Sackville report put, they included the proposal that the proceedings of certain courts be open to the electronic media, and television in particular-a proposition which I and the member for Banks are very strongly opposed to, and I reiterate my opposition to that proposition. The Sackville report proposals also included: the development of a single national market for legal services; the establishment of mechanisms to ensure that clients are provided with far greater information by lawyers about their circumstances, the proceedings that they may be involved in and the services that are to be provided for them; a proposal that lawyers be required to provide written quotes to clients, roughly in the same way that tradespeople usually do; and proposals to provide for limited options with respect to contingency fees, with which I have some reservations but which, as they were developed, seem to me to be fairly cautious and reasonable. There were also proposals for independent complaints bodies to scrutinise lawyers and the delivery of legal services-a proposition which I am extremely strongly attracted to--and strategies to eliminate some of the many procedural delays and tangles that tend to cause enormous problems in our court system. Most of these proposals, of course, related to state jurisdiction matters and I am pleased to say that some of them, in various forms, are being pursued by some of the states. I do not necessarily agree with everything that the Victorian Attorney-General, Jan Wade, has done in her time in that office. In fact, there is an awful lot that I disagree with, but I do at least acknowledge her courage and willingness to tackle issues of legal reform along these lines. However, there is a long way to go on many of these issues. I was present, along with other members of the House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, at a discussion with the Law Council of Australia some weeks ago and it was very interesting to discuss some of these issues with the council. One of the points that I raised with them was: how serious was their commitment to the notion of a national uniform market for legal services when they continue to defend the existence of separate professions in states like Victoria? The result is that we have a situation where what a lawyer can and cannot do in South Australia, for example, is different from what a lawyer can and cannot do in Victoria. A barrister in Victoria is unable to perform services that fall within the traditional scope of a solicitor, whereas in South Australia you have a merged profession. It would seem to me that, if you are going to have a uniform national market for legal services, one of the most obvious components of uniformity is that the various players in that market can do the same things, and deliver the same services, irrespective of what state of _he Commonwealth they happen to be in. I was disappointed to see that the Law Council did not seem to see any contradiction in those two positions. Nonetheless, I do feel that the winds of change are blowing fairly strongly through the legal profession and it is pleasing to see that there is impetus for this coming from both sides of politics. Although there is considerable work to be done, I have no doubt that, over the next 10 years or so, major change is going to occur which will be of benefit to the community, both to lower income earners, who in many respects are excluded from legal services, and also to the community generally in the sense of improving economic efficiency and reducing costs that legal services do constitute. Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 329 Having made those background remarks I now tum to the content of the government's Justice Statement. It is based on three key themes-prevention, reform, and equality and social justice. I would like to run through some of the basics of the statement, as the first government speaker. Firstly, concerning family mediation strategies, $18.7 million over four years is allocated to a variety of initiatives associated with marriage and relationship courses, family skills training, the development of eight new adolescent mediation and family therapy services, and up to 20 new financial counselling services. And an amount of $13.5 million over four years is allocated for the Family Court to increase counselling services and registries in provincial and rural Australia. Secondly, in the area of criminal law, in a safer Australia strategy, $7.3 million is to be spent over four years. That entails a variety of prevention oriented measures, further work on the development of a model criminal code, the establishment of a national missing persons bureau, and, perhaps most importantly, work on pursuing tighter gun controls. It is not an issue that tends to get debated a great deal in the federal parliament but, for the record, my view is that tighter gun controls are essential. I would support very strongly further restricting access to guns in our community. The third category of initiatives is associated with the general delivery of legal services. We will see the establishment of an Australian legal assistance board which is intended to coordinate and plan the delivery of legal aid assistance across the country. There is to be $24 million spent over four years for more legal assistance, particularly focusing on family and civil law cases. An amount of $30 million over four years has been allocated for the doubling of the community legal centres' budget and that involves the establishment of nine new community legal centres across the country, something that I will say more about in a minute. An amount of $10 million has been allocated to a national disbursements assistance fund which, in effect, will enable the funding up-front of public interest cases. For example, environmental cases and the like which otherwise would not have been able to be funded will now be funded. There is to be a women's justice strategy, which the honourable member for Pearce( Mrs Moylan) has applauded. I note her support for that and I will say more about her comments in a minute. There will be $17 million spent over four years on specialist women's legal centres in each capital city. There is to be a toll-free phone service. There will be specialist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander services within the framework of those women's legal centres. And, as the honourable member for Pearce outlined, there will be an outreach service for women consumers of legal services in remote and rural areas. Then we have the strategy to reform procedures and the profession, which, of course, largely depends on cooperation with the states and negotiations with the states about change. As part of that, there is to be an overhaul of the Federal Court fee scales and the initiation of a Prices Surveillance Authority study of lawyers' fees, both of which are welcome initiatives. A strategy will also be developed to assist courts and tribunals to develop charters of access to their services and to simplify their rules and procedures. We will develop strategies to tackle the backlog of cases which so many courts in Australia are bedevilled by. There is also a strategy to develop judicial education, professional development training, with respect to things such as cross-cultural awareness and gender issues awareness. MC 330 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 There are specific initiatives with respect to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders such as funding for interpreter training and Family Court outreach services and similar initiatives with respect to people of non-English speaking background. In overall terms, I applaud the Justice Statement. I have had a fair degree of involvement in the past with community legal centres. The increased provision of services through community legal centres is a major initiative. There are many people in our community for whom the only serious prospect of access to legal services is via local community legal centres. There are many parts of the country-not those I represent, I hasten to add-where people have no real access to community legal services. If they lack the income and the wealth to be able to get ordinary legal services, then those people are left high and dry. For many common or garden, mundane legal problems, be they criminal problems in the Magistrate's Court-perhaps somebody has pranged their car and they cannot get the other person to pay up because they are uninsured-civil problems or disputes and the like, in a very high proportion of these cases people are unable to get justice. The barrier that prevents them getting justice is the high cost of participating in our legal system. I applaud women's legal centres because it is very obvious that there are many legal issues which are focused on gender questions. I can only cite my own experience as a trade union official dealing with sexual harassment matters where the general preference for female victims of sexual harassment, very understandably, was to be represented by a female union official. It seems perfectly reasonable to me to have gender specific areas in legal services because there will be many areas where it will be of much greater benefit and assistance to women consumers to be able to deal with things on a gender specific basis. I also applaud the assistance to environmental and other cases-which I expect will be offered through the national disbursements assistance fund-and prevention strategies with respect to crime and family problems. It is not only in the health area that prevention tends to be a very poor relation. In legal and criminal areas, prevention also tends to be neglected. It is long overdue that we pursue a more prevention oriented strategy. This is a very worthwhile initiative. I have already made some comments on procedure reform and the reform of the profession and I applaud anything that is done in that regard. I am sure anybody who has experienced some of the Byzantine procedural arrangements in areas like the Victorian Supreme Court and elsewhere would applaud the initiatives designed to improve those things and to make them more accessible and less expensive. Finally, before I tum to comments made by the honourable member for Pearce, it is worth noting that what this Justice Statement ultimately shows is that, even in a budget that was necessarily contractionary, this Labor government is still able to deliver on important social justice initiatives. After 12 years in office, it is still reforming and pursuing basic Labor programs that help people who are on lower incomes and suffer as a result of having less wealth than many others in society. Access to legal services and justice is a critical component of being able to participate fully in our society. It is great that, at this advanced stage of being in government, we are still pursuing initiatives like this. There is a lot more to be done. I am sure the government will continue to do it. Finally, I tum to some of the comments of the honourable member for Pearce. I am almost tempted to offer her membership of the Left of the Labor Party for some of the things that she said. It was very good to hear her criticising the government for reducing funding on Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 331 domestic violence education and saying how we have not given enough money to the women's initiatives in the Justice Statement. WhatI would point out is that the person speaking was somebody who was elected to parliament, along with my honourable colleagues opposite, on a platform which centred on reducing federal government expenditure by $10 billion per annum. has a long list of efficiencies that he would be able to pursue. There is an obvious hypocrisy in that, again, the coalition is attempting to criticise the government from the left. That is our job. You just stick to your job, which is being neanderthal. It is grossly hypocritical to be attacking the government for not spending more money in areas of social assistance to lower income people when you know, just as well as we know, that in the unlikely event that you ever get into government these will be the very first programs that will not only be cut but completely abolished. There would be very little of this access to justice strategy that would survive the election of a Howard government. Much as I applaud the comments of the honourable member for Pearce, I suggest that, if she is serious about the views she is expressing, she should consider which party she is in. range of subjects, and I want to deal in the main with chapter 8, which deals with consumer protection issues, but I naturally must comment on some of the empty gongs and clashing cymbals that were so evident in the contribution of the member for Melbourne ( Mr Tanner). Indeed, Labor has been very good about the rhetoric of social justice, but its actual achievements have, of course, been abysmal. The Prime Minister( Mr Keating) looked decidedly uncomfortable in delivering a justice and equity statement, because those are areas where he has never taken any significant interest and where his own performance and results have been utterly abysmal. Whilst somebody no doubt wrote the right words for him, he clearly did not have his heart in them, because his objectives have always been elsewhere. Indeed, after more than a decade of Labor rule, we clearly now have a much more unequal society than we had when Labor came to office. If that is their record of social justice and social equity, then there is indeed a need for a major turnaround, for a new direction, and so a policy statement on these sorts of issues was long overdue. Unfortunately, the statement is, however, long on rhetoric. It contains many words which are obviously supportable-motherhood statements of support for all the good things of life-but, in reality, very few initiatives which are likely to achieve much to benefit the Australian people through better access to justice or greater equity in policy delivery. I am especially concerned that many of the matters that are referred to require legislative action; yet, as I look through the legislative program, the reforms to the Trade Practices Act which are central to the consumer protection elements of this statement are not on the program for the rest of this year. That gives you some idea about the level of government commitment. We had a grand statement and plenty of rhetoric last May, but none of the legislation dealing with these matters is going to see the light of day in this parliament-because we all know that this is virtually certain to be its last session. The Prime Minister is saying, 'Here is a long list of Labor objectives, none of which will be achieved by the election; but you have got to believe in us as you believed in the tax cuts and all of the election promises last time, if you want to see any of them delivered.' theText: Thank you very much for your protection, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I canWednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 333 and consultations with the states, which generally have the legislative power in this area. Past history suggests that it can be a very slow process to achieve this sort of agreement. In fact, the Director of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, Jenni Mack, in commenting on this particular initiative, and welcoming it, stressed that its success would depend on actions by the states and on uniform agreements reached by the Council of Australian Governments. She then threw in the very obvious comment that these are bodies 'not noted for quick or consultative decision making'. Sadly, there is a long process likely to be required to achieve that degree of uniformity. The coalition will soon be in government and will have the responsibility of implementing this announcement. It is committed to vigorously pursuing the development of uniform and readily understood consumer protection laws and it will be working and encouraging the states to work towards that objective as a very high priority. There are some areas which obviously need immediate attention. For example, there are areas where transactions which cross state borders can make it difficult for manufacturers and suppliers to comply with appropriate standards, and there are areas where appropriate dispute resolution procedures are not available because state boundaries get in the way. These sorts of things need to be addressed as a matter of priority. I also welcome the proposal to develop standards for consumer complaint schemes. One of the positive developments over recent times has been the development at state and national level of industry based ombudsman schemes. It has to be said that some of these are working very much better than others. The obvious example of dismal performance has been the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. In fact, that has got off to such a bad start that there is an inquiry in the other place at the present time going on into its performance. A real problem with the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal is the lack of a broad based jurisdiction. It is interesting to note that more than half of all of the written complaints that have been given to the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal have been struck out because of lack of jurisdiction. In addition, there were 5,188 telephone enquiries which led to only 881 written complaints. The obvious reason for that is that the telephone inquiry quickly established that the body in most instances did not have jurisdiction over the areas of concern. The one obvious problem is that the complaints tribunal has so far not had the capacity to deal with medical evidence. They were promised that they would have that jurisdiction by May but then the government backed off and now there is a promise that it will be there by November. Frankly, any further delays by the government will be unacceptable. I am concerned though that there are so many other matters that the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal seems unable to deal with. I think all of us in our electorate offices have had complaints over recent times about the very poor performance of many superannuation funds and generally that is also outside the jurisdiction of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. There are few things that the Tribunal can actually deal with but even those that it deals with proceed so very slowly that in a year since it began operation over $1 million of taxpayer-' money has already been spent and it has the grand record so far of handing down 12 decisions. It has 416 active cases and, of those, 321 were still at the inquiry conciliation stage, 83 had completed the inquiry and conciliation, but only 12 had gone to the review hearings. So this is an example of an ombudsman scheme that has really got a long way to go to be considered effective. MC 334 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 On the other hand, also in the insurance field are the general insurance industry review panels. I think their performance has been quite commendable. They deal in detail with the matters put before them and consumers have a very good record, with about 55 per cent of all of the reviews finding in favour of the consumer. The way in which they deal with issues seems to be thorough, efficient and commendable. Of course, not everyone is always happy with all of the findings but, frankly, some of the stories that are put before them would make really good novels. It is amazing what some consumers try to put over their insurance companies, too, so fault is not always on one side. This body has done well in trying to deal with those issues, and it is interesting that the number of complaints is reducing. I think that is a sign that the industry itself is responding to consumer concerns by adopting better standards and being prepared to recognise that business and industry have a responsibility also to their consumers. There is a proposal in the statement to work towards developing common standards of independence, impartiality, accessibility, efficiency, effectiveness, openness and accountability. If there is to be widespread consumer confidence in the ombudsman schemes, particularly when they are industry based, this sort of thing is desirable. The coalition is also happy to commit itself to working towards the development of a more comprehensive ombudsman system to ensure that in every instance high standards are not only set but actually achieved. That is a very worthwhile objective. There is also a need to look at gaps in the ombudsman schemes to ensure that no areas of complaint fall between the various jurisdictions. There are a number of examples of that at the present time, and I hope that this proposed review can deal also with that sort of issue. It is important that the various ombudsman offices maintain integrity and are regarded by the community as balanced and fair in assessing the various issues that are before them. Some very worthwhile initiatives are being taken up in this area. I notice that the Trade Practices Commission, presumably eventually the ACCC, its successor, is also to be given greater powers and resources to pursue consumer protection issues. That is also an important initiative. I suspect that because of a lack of resources the Trade Practices Commission has tended to devote maximum effort to corporate fraud, crime and major issues that are headline grabbing. Ordinary consumers with perhaps just their own complaint against a particular manufacturer or a supplier feel that their issue is not being regarded by the Trade Practices Commission as worthy of having the necessary resources devoted to it. That is disappointing because the Trade Practices Commission needs to be a body that supports the little person as well as deal with the high-fliers in Australian industry. There are also proposals to deal with post-sale consumer protection, which has been identified in many areas as a matter of considerable concern. I believe that the issues I have mentioned are important, and it is good to see consumer issues being addressed in a justice and equity statement. As I have said, however, so far the government has not demonstrated any capacity to act to support its empty rhetoric and it is now time for some action. (Time expired) suggest to the honourable member for Wide Bay( Mr Truss) that the words he used, 'empty, hollow comment', are very appropriate to what we have just heard in this place today.

speaker: Mr Cleeland (Mcewen)(L2.01 P.m.)
theText: In rising to speak on the Justice Statement, IWednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 335 We really are faced with a totally policy free opposition. For members of the opposition to stand up in this place and criticise the government for the Justice Statement when they do not have one policy point to raise is nothing but empty, hollow rhetoric. When we look at access to justice, the first thing we in this parliament always should recognise is that the bulk of justice is in the hands of state governments, not the federal government. The vast bulk of Australian citizens who have recourse to legal proceedings do so through state instrumentalities: the courts of summary justice, the district county courts and the supreme courts of the states. If we look at the states, which are now principally controlled by the opposition parties, we can see the attitude to access to justice. If we look at Victoria and at the Liberal-National party coalition governing it, the first thing we notice is massive cuts to legal aid, and in the actions of the Liberal and National parties we see a denial of access to the courts. In Victoria today, large numbers of people appear daily in magistrates' courts charged with offences which have the potential for conviction and gaol. These people appear in court totally unrepresented because the National Party and the Liberal Party in that state do not care about access to justice. Community legal centres and community organisations in Victoria are being slashed to the bone, ripped into by the government, while coalition party members stand here and say, with hollow rhetoric, how concerned they are about access to justice. If they are really concerned they should go to Victoria and talk to Jeffrey Kennett and say, 'Put your money where your mouth is,' but, no, they sit up here policy free, with no suggestions for change, and are critical. They should just go to Victoria where the people know full well what the Liberal and National parties stand for: it is certainly not to provide access to justice for ordinary Australian citizens. This is a very important and innovative statement that the government has brought forward. As my colleague the member for Melbourne ( Mr Tanner) correctly pointed out, it is evidence of a government which has not lost its way and which is maintaining its Labor priorities in ensuring that ordinary people are provided with appropriate services and access to justice, because a denial of access is a denial of justice. People who do not get access to legal services have no justice at all. Many points have been raised in the debate so far and there are several that I want to touch on. The first is the increasing tendency for the legal profession in Australia, encouraged by governments of both political persuasions, to charge what are known as contingency fees. It is a process whereby a legal firm can advertise and say, 'We will handle any legal case without fee unless we win,' in other words, 'You come to us and take potluck at our financial risk and we will sue who you want us to sue and we will do what we can to get you megabucks.' Let me say that I dislike such a process intensely; I find it offensive. Increasingly I am very worried about the way our legal professionals are going when they are advertising along the lines of 'Come in at no risk and we will sue.' I oppose it and I think we are heading the way of the United States whereby we will have legal firms in this country issuing or inventing quite outrageous causes of action simply for the fact that they can take 10, 20 or 30 per cent of the gain if they are successful. That is what is happening in the United States, the most litigious country in the world, with a legal system I find appalling, unprofessional and outrageous, and I am very concerned that that is the way we are going in this country. I just want to place on record today that, when it comes to access to justice, I do not think that improves justice and I do not think it improves MC 336 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 access. It prostitutes, in my view, the legal profession; it is unprofessional. Other people may disagree with that, but I am firmly of that view. The other thing that worries me greatly also, as a former practising lawyer, is the enormous increase in the number of lawyers in this country. There is in Victoria, my home state, a lawyer on every street corner struggling to make a living out of a diminishing share of the marketplace as the numbers of lawyers increase. As in any group of people who need to make a living, they will stretch professional integrity to the nth degree in order to maintain a living in a very tight marketplace. I really think it is a great tragedy that young people are still flocking into our law schools seeking law degrees on the basis that they will enter private practice when there is simply no room for these people in private practice. I find it quite alarming that the number of law undergraduates in Australian universities today is larger than the number of current practising lawyers in Australia. If you stop to think about those figures, when each of these young people coming out with a white collar and a law degree has an expectation of a right to earn a good income, the fact is that they are not going to make it. You wonder what the legal professional in a professional sense is going to be like when it is going to be so overcrowded and so difficult to make a living. You see that today in Victoria, where the number of lawyers defaulting is increasing at an exponential rate. A profession I was proud to be a member of is now being viewed by the public as just a lot of leeches sucking on the public purse. It saddens me greatly that a profession that has got a long tradition in this country is seeing so many of its members dipping into their trust funds and basically stealing other people's money. I do not know about other states but certainly in Victoria it is happening at an alarming rate, and yet increasingly we are being told we should deregulate more, we should take away controls on lawyers and let the market work its own forces. That worries me-I suspect that lawyers are under-regulated today-much as it used to annoy me as a former practising lawyer that there were all the auditing rules and the sheer amount of paperwork you had to do to maintain your trust account and your practice. If lawyers as a profession are going to breach the basics of honesty and integrity, then there is only one way to treat them, and that is to regulate them further so that we try and stop that kind of activity taking place. I have mentioned my concerns about legal aid and I am pleased that the Commonwealth at least is looking at means of increasing legal aid. My worry there, though, is that, as the Commonwealth increases its contributions to the states, in Victoria they keep cutting them. This seems to be a pattern in Victoria. If you take Medicare, for example, in 1993 the Commonwealth signed a new Medicare agreement in Victoria and an additional sum of $500 million of Commonwealth funding flowed into the Victorian health system. Within two months of that statement, the Victorian Liberal-National party government cut $380 million of state funding to health and hence we have had over 800 beds closed. This is what happens in legal aid: anything we increase in funding, the Victorian Liberal-National party government immediately cut, so there is no greater access or no greater benefit for the people of Victoria. We will see this again-that, as we increase the Commonwealth contribution to legal aid, we will see the Victorian Liberal-National party government increasingly cut their own component, and so pedple will be worse off in terms of accessing legal aid. Legal aid is essential, absolutely essential. As I said, it worries me greatly that I could walk into Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 337 magistrates' courts in Victoria and see people facing the court without any legal representation at all, often not even knowing the structure of the offence with which they are being charged and often not even knowing the consequences of a conviction-and that conviction often carries a term of imprisonment. If our system is going to go that way, such that people face imprisonment without proper legal advice, I think this country will stand condemned for not providing sufficient resources to ensure that every person facing a gaol sentence is adequaldy an'; t ivperly l-presel",:d, whether it be in a magistrate's court, a district court, a county court or a supreme court. Of course, it is true that superior courts, such as the Supreme Court, will not allow people facing capital charges-such as homicide, for example-to appear before the court unrepresented. Even though we no longer have capital punishment, the history of that goes back to the day when superior courts said that no-one should face without representation a trial where the punishment was death. We do not have it any more, thank God. Nevertheless, the courts still maintain the view that on serious charges a person must be represented. It seems to me that that principle-that people who face courts are entitled to appropriate and proper representation-should be carried through, as a matter of right, in this country. It may well be that the profession itself stands to be condemned for the excessive fees that it sometimes charges. But I am led to believe that, in Victoria now, even middle-ranking barristers will do a Magistrate's Court appearance for around $250 or $300, which is basically what it was some 10 years ago, when I was in practice. So maybe the competition and number of lawyers in the system is actually reducing the cost of legal service in the courts. I have mentioned my great concern about contingency fees. I really am quite horrified by the way this country is following the American system. May I say, with no disrespect to the United States, that there is nothing that country can teach us. There is nothing it can teach us in terms of social policy, and nothing it can teach us in terms of anything which involves decency, because its legal system is so appalling. Quite often, one just cannot believe it. Their social system is such that people fall out through the bottom. To stand outside the White House in Washington and be surrounded, every way I look, by homeless people, in the middle of what is said to be the world's wealthiest country, makes me come back and say there is nothing the United States can teach us. Yet we still seem to want to follow some of the things this most appalling-in social terms--country quite often does. There are a lot of things here that really please me. I think the increase in funding for community legal centres is very important. Some years back, I spent every second Friday night at a legal referral centre run by the local council at the Greensborough shopping centre. Most of the local lawyers in Greensborough, in those years, did provide that service on a Friday night. It was really interesting legal work to actually have people come in off the streets, able to access competent legal advice at no fee or cost, and to be advising on which way they should or should not go with the particular concerns they had. I have often thought that we really need to have a lot more of those shopfront legal services available in Australia, and the fact that there is $30 million provided for in the Justice Statement for community legal centres, which doubles the existing funding, is indeed very pleasing. The other difficulty which the Justice Statement is seeking to redress is the difficulty that many people who were born outside of this country have with language communication in our justice system. There is no doubt at all that a lot of people who we think can communicate in English really do not understand the nature of the legal problem they are facing, be it civil MC 338 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 or criminal, because of different comprehensions of the use of words. I think it is essential, if we are going to have decent justice in this country, that people who do have legal difficulties, either civil or criminal, are able to access competent and well-trained interpreters to assist them. That is another measure which is there. Another matter, which again pleases me, is looking at the Federal Court scales and initiating a Prices Surveillance Authority survey on lawyers fees. Our profession in Australia is a profession divided between the bar and solicitors. Even though in Victoria that was fused, in some states it is still a separate profession, and barristers need to be brought back into a fee scale system which is capable of public scrutiny. It is offensive when people can charge the sort of money that top QCs are capable of charging today, when they are the minority of the total profession and they take the biggest slice of the public cake in legal aid funding. (Time expired) issued by the government is, to my mind, an outstanding statement in canvassing all of those issues with which it deals. It is comprehensive and thorough, and certainly brings together a lot of the issues that have been of concern to the Australian community over a long period of time, as the member for McEwen( Mr Cleeland) indicated. The report is based on the Sackville committee report on access to justice. That committee reported last year. It made something in excess of 70 recommendations-which, to a very large extent, provided a solid approach to the types of reform that are necessary within the legal system. Especially did it deal with the problems of inadequate access to justice and the inefficiencies of the court systems. The range and number of those recommendations brought home to everyone who was aware of the report the nature of the inequity which relates to the Australian legal system and the fact-again, as Peter Cleeland just indicated-that it tends now to focus more on rewarding the practitioners within that legal system than on dispensing justice to those who can afford to pay for it or to the majority of people who have become trapped in a costly legal maze. One of the fundamental elements of the system that we live in is, and must be, the right of people to access the legal system, to have their grievances heard and redressed and, where necessary, to have judgment made by their peers. They are fundamental, basic elements; but, as a result of the complexity and cost of the legal system, to a very large extent they are becoming something which is not available to Australian citizens. To a large extent, that is what the Justice Statement attempts to deal with. It is a comprehensive statement. It covers 188 pages. I am not going to go through the contents, but I am heartened by the fact that chapter 1 deals with families. People express concerns about family instability and family breakups and the legal maze often associated with that: questions of what we used to call access and custody. Fortunately, a lot of the terminology is changing, but the difficulty being confronted by people in those circumstances has not materially improved. It has got worse. Perhaps the government's commitment to those changes contained now in the Justice Statement will make it possible for us to start to redress some of those growing inadequacies. When the Justice Statement was launched by the Prime Minister( Mr Keating), with what I should also say was an outstanding statement by the Prime Minister, there were some reputable commentators who responded very well to it. I refer firstly to the editorial in the

speaker: Mr Robert Brown (Charlton) (12.16 P.m.)
theText: The Justice Statement which has beenWednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 339 Australian. I will read the first paragraph of that, because I think it is important that it get into our records just the same as it is in the public record of the media. The Australian said: The Federal Government's justice statement is welcome for its promise to make the law financially fairer and more accessible. They are the two fundamental elements of that Justice Statement: financially fairer and more accessible. The editorial went on to say: In a democratic society such laudable purpose cannot sensibly be contradicted. There is political wisdom behind the decision to establish women's legal centres in each State and Territory-adding resources to family mediation and support services as well as allocating more money for legal aid advice. There is also merit in the proposals to reduce costs for the ordinary litigant and to boost public confidence in the justice system. This package, taken in total, sets a reasonable direction for reform. That is a sensible, intelligent, balanced, reputable response. But there were some cynics as well within the media. The Sydney Morning Herald is a major metropolitan paper in New South Wales with great tradition behind it over a long period of time, but the last paragraph of its editorial said: It is, perhaps, being unduly cynical to see the reforms as handouts to interest groups who will be vocal during the next Federal election campaign. CouldI say to the editorial writers of the Sydney Morning Herald, 'Yes, that is being unduly cynical.' Do they expect us to suspend government? Or if the opposition at some time in the long distant future comes into government, will the Sydney Morning Herald editorial writers expect them to suspend government before elections? Should governments suspend their initiatives? Do governments need to suspend the responsibility that they have to overcome injustice and to give people financially affordable access to the court system just because there is an election coming up? That is not very smart on the part of the Sydney Morning Herald, not very smart at all. Let me say again, 'Yes, it would be unduly cynical for them to make such a claim.' Let me put it into context. Because the Sydney Morning Herald and a lot of the other media commentators have become accustomed to good government, their judgments become harsher and they become more demanding. That is understandable. A fine day gives you a measure against which you assess what the alternatives might be. If you do not have the fine days, you do not know how bad the crook ones are; but when you have a fine day, it can always be just a little bit better. That is what the community and some elements of the media do with this government. We have provided good government. But as the Prime Minister says from time to time, every time we do something good, the commentators and the community lift the bar, like the high jump. 'Well,' they say, 'you have done pretty well. You got across that bar. Now try that.' And you get across that one and they say, 'Now try that.' The bar rises all the time. Let us put this Justice Statement, a great statement, into context. I say it is part of the whole mosaic of good government. Since we have been in government, we have been responsible for the most significant period of industry restructuring that this country has ever seen. Australian industry now, as it was never before, is competitive; it is flexible, it is adaptable, it is efficient-right across industry. I know there are problems. In the process of that restructuring, problems emerge. And, yes, we have looked after those people as well to a very large extent, the people who would have been bearing the burden of that restructuring. We have been fiscally stringent. We have been fiscally responsible. For the first time in the history of the Commonwealth, during the 1980s there were four occasions, Mr Deputy Speaker, MC 340 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 as you would recall, when this government budgeted for a surplus. Everyone wants a surplus, and we gave them four-with a cumulative surplus of $18 billion over those four years. We did it again this year, and they said 'Oh yes, but that's only because you are selling assets.' We have been fiscally responsible. We have been fiscally stringent. We have provided a safety net in the area of social security or welfare. We have provided real increases in benefits to the less advantaged people in the community. We have finely targeted where those benefits go. We have extended the range of services to make sure that the safety net for those people in Australia is adequate so that they do not fall through it, and that people do not drop in and take advantage of the safety net when they do not need to. We have restructured our priorities in the total budget. We have balanced social programs. We have developed infrastructure. We have assisted the states in a more adequate, more targeted way than was ever done before. We have restructured our defence commitment and we have done the same thing with overseas aid. More recently, we had the One Nation statement-one of the most significant statements that any government has ever provided in terms of indicating the nature, direction and volume of investment in national infrastructure. After that One Nation statement, people said, 'Well, that is pretty good, that is okay, but now what are you going to do?' We said, 'We will do something about the unemployment. We will have the Working Nation statement. We will target an increase of half a million jobs.' The next day they said, 'That was pretty good, but now what are you going to do?' We said, 'What we want to do is to determine the pattern for the future development of arts, craft, music, drama, skills and culture of the Australian people and so we will have the Creative Nation.' 'Oh, yeah,' they said, 'That's okay, but now what are you going to do?' So we said, 'Look, as a result of the Mabo decision, the indigenous people of Australia deserve additional attention and we will legislate on the basis of that. We will give those people a level of justice they never had before. Not only that, but we will give them a land fund to make sure that the most dispossessed are able to get back some of that land.' They said, 'Yeah, well, that's all right, but now what are you going to do?' So we said, 'We'll talk about a vision for where this nation is going. We will talk about a vision for the pride, dignity, sovereignty, independence and self-assertion of this nation in terms of the republic that's going to occur in the future.' That was pretty well received as well and they said, 'Well, what else are you going to do?' So we gave them a budget with a surplus. They said, 'That wasn't a bad budget, but what are you going to do tomorrow?' So we gave them the Justice Statement. Some of the media, as I say, are pretty cynical about it. Perhaps some members of the community are as well. That is understandable. We can carry that burden because we know that that burden of criticism and cynicism is visited on us because we have provided good government. When we bring in our innovation statement, they will say with a yawn, 'Oh, yeah, well, what are you going to do next?' I think they have been pretty tough in their judgment. This has been good government. This has been outstanding government. Of course there have been individual problems, individual inadequacies. There have been problems that have been created as a result of all those changes, initiatives and vision. We have made sure that where problems were created we gave attention to them as well. The Justice Statement gives priority to women's legal services, legal aid funding, the Family Court and community law centres. They are the types of things to which attention has been Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 341 given but, at the same time, a whole range of other things have also been considered. On the question of effective competition within the legal service, we have found the value of competition in Australia by building efficiency and bringing down costs and prices. The same applies to the legal profession. The questions of legal fees, gender bias on the part of judges, the wigged and gowned members of the court system and televising court proceedings are addressed. I know my colleague the member for Banks( Mr Melham), who is an eminent legal person and chairs the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, has reservations about that. I do as well. I do not want Australian courts turned into a circus. I have seen circuses in other countries and I know the effect they have, not only on the position of those people, but also on the question of justice. The questions of consumer protection and the settlement of disputes outside the legal system were also given consideration in the report. It is a good report and a good statement. It reflects good, sound and continuing government. (Time expired) going to make some general comments later in my speech, but I want to talk initially about the benefit of this Justice Statement to my electorate in Cairns and Far North Queensland. Families in my electorate will directly benefit from a range of new services in the $160 million Justice Statement, which outlines a comprehensive national strategy for creating a simpler, cheaper and more accessible justice system. Cairns and Far North Queensland have already received significant federal government assistance to provide legal services and family counselling from this government. The Cairns Community Legal Service received more than $158,200 to assist in providing community legal services, as well as dedicated funding for disability, discrimination, legal advice and advocacy. It means that, as well as a general lawyer employed by the Cairns Community Legal Centre, there is also an advocate in discrimination law. More than $63,300 has also been allocated to Centacare in Cairns to provide marriage and relationship education and counselling in 1994-95. In addition, Youth Link in Cairns received more than $117,700 for adolescent mediation and family therapy. As part of a four-year program under the Justice Statement, the government has significantly expanded community based services to help families in Cairns and Far North Queensland overcome legal problems. New support services, such as marriage relationship education services and at least one new financial counselling service, will be established in the Cairns and Far North Queensland region for funding under the Justice Statement. The government will also fund the Family Court to upgrade its Cairns registry-which is very significant-to give better access to Family Court services for people in Far North Queensland. The government's strategy encourages mediation in family law matters to help minimise the trauma of marriage break-up. It will increase the availability of counselling and mediation services throughout the Cairns and Far North Queensland region with new community based mediation services. The Justice Statement funding will also build on these existing services with establishment of a specialist women's service linked to the existing women's service in Brisbane. It will be part of a national network of women's legal services established in response to the needs of women for specialist legal assistance in areas such as domestic violence and family law matters.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Dodd (Leichhardt) (12.31 P.m.)
theText: I support the government's Justice Statement. I amMC 342 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 As part of the overhaul of the legal aid system, the Commonwealth will substantially increase funding for legal aid commissions and community legal centres, such as the Cairns Legal Community Centre, while developing innovative new ways of meeting legal costs, such as the national disbursement assistance fund, which I will speak about later. Also, there has been an announcement by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney General( Mr Duncan) that an Environmental Defender's Office will be located in either Cairns or Townsville. I will certainly do everything I can to make sure it comes to Cairns. It will be funded to $70,000 and will become part of a national network made up of environmental defender's offices in every state and territory. I had an input into this part of the Justice Statement. I was lobbied by the national environmental defender's office organisation and I subsequently lobbied both the Attorney General( Mr Lavarch) and the Minister for Justice( Mr Kerr) on this issue. I consider it very important that legal advice is available to community groups and individuals in relation to environmental law matters. These matters are very important in my electorate and in a lot of other parts of Australia. We need to be able to provide people with adequate advice because, quite often, the people on the other side of these disputes-developers and the like-are well equipped to access advice. I am not saying I am against all development and developers, but they quite often have very good access to legal resources whereas community groups do not, and that is why this initiative is very important. Very clearly, the Justice Statement presented by the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) was very good for my constituents in that it addresses a lot of the problems they face in relation to access to justice. I now have some general comments about the statement, particularly with regard to the future, based on my personal experience as a lawyer and solicitor. I have had experience in private practice, I have worked as a salaried lawyer for legal aid commissions in two states, and I have also worked for the Public Trustee in Queensland-a body which, until recently, provided a great deal of free legal advice in a different area of the law to the people of Queensland. It is a great disappointment to me that the Public Trustee decided last year--or perhaps early this year-to withdraw a lot of its services. That decision was certainly not in the spirit of the Justice Statement, and I ask the Queensland government to consider reversing the decision and restoring the Public Trustee services. People in remote areas, such as many in my electorate, received advice on drafting of wills, for example, and it also gave advice in relation to estates and the like. I hope that the Queensland government will read the Justice Statement and perhaps adjust that situation. The advisory committee that produced the Justice Statement stated that there had been a lack of strategic direction at the national level on legal aid policy, resulting in inefficiencies and unequal access to legal aid. That is certainly an understatement. If you go to one state, you might be eligible for legal aid for one legal problem but, if you go to another, you may be ineligible. Some states have more stringent means tests than do other states. Some states have merit tests for some matters and some states do not. So it becomes a bit of a lottery. I will talk more about lotteries later because, to some extent, we still have a legal system where access to justice is unfortunately a lottery. I applaud the measures in the statement to reverse this situation. They involve a more active Commonwealth role in legal aid policy and administration, which I welcome. An Australian Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 343 legal assistance board will be given $16.8 million over four years for delivery of legal services in civil and family law. That is over and additional to the mainstay of the Legal Aid Commission, which is criminal law. Balancing civil and criminal law obligations for legal aid is a very difficult task for any legal aid commission. Some legal aid commissions have merit tests for criminal matters, and it seems to me that it probably is appropriate to have means tested delivery of services when there are limited resources. However, it is totally inappropriate to have merit tests in criminal matters. Basically, this initiative allows the legal aid commissions to prejudge the matter and to reverse the onus of proof. In lay terms, that is a reversal of the principle of innocent until proven guilty, and is something that should be avoided. If only criminal matters are given legal aid, ordinary citizens feel that the legal aid system excludes them. Of course, a perfect legal system would be one which provides for a right to legal assistance for people in at least serious criminal matters, and a targeted system, by merit and means tested, for both civil and family law, supplemented perhaps by something like the national disbursement assistance fund that we have got in the Justice Statement. But we do not have a perfect system because there is a limit to funding by government or any other sources. My belief is that there at least has to be some commitment by all states and the Commonwealth to fund legal aid from their budgets and not rely on solicitors' trust accounts or some other source in that regard. The reality is that, if you rely on solicitors' trust accounts, when there is a downturn in the economy, a downturn in legal work, that is often a time when you need more legal aid funds and that is a time when those solicitors' trust funds go down. So there has to be a commitment, I believe, from all states and the Commonwealth to provide legal assistance from the budget. I make the following comments. They are not on behalf of the government, but I think that, if we are going to have an equitable legal system in the future, we have got to really look beyond the Justice Statement and look to some sort of wholesale restructuring of the legal system in terms of delivery of legal services and also in terms of the litigation system. I think that in the future, if I might predict, we will have a legal care system as we have now got a Medicare system. I think in the long run that is the only way to provide justice and equity in terms of access to the legal system. Mr Nehl interjectingis: how are you going to fund it? I think that the public, if it wants an accessible justice system, has to accept that there may be the need for some sort of levy like the Medicare levy. To keep costs down it would have to underwritten by perhaps professional indemnity schemes and some financial incentives. I think that that is one wing of a very important reform. The other wing of an important reform that would keep costs down is to implement-as the Whitlam government tried to do though it was thwarted by the Senate and the events of 1975-a no-fault compensation scheme. At the moment it is a lottery. If you go to one stateand I use that phrase advisedly-you get one award for a particular injury; if you go to another you get another award. If you happen to be lucky enough to be in a motor car and you lose your leg, you are at least covered by a compulsory scheme. But in Queensland, for example, if that happens because someone assaults you, you have got no hope of recovering, certainly
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Dodd
theText: I did not hear the honourable member's interjection but the obvious responseMC 344 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 in relation to any criminal compensation scheme. Of course, workers compensation schemes also would come into that. Contrast that situation, where people have difficulty in receiving any sort of compensation when they are bashed senseless by someone in the streets, with a situation-and I do not want to make any comment about the person-such as the one where the courts in New South Wales awarded about $300,000 to Andrew Ettingshausen, money for damages arising out of a proven defamation because he was inadvertently exposed in some magazine. The public just do not see that as fair and equitable. The only way to resolve that is to really have a no-fault scheme coupled with greater access to legal aid. Then there might be eventually a fair and equitable scheme. In the short time that I have got left I just want to make some general comments about matters that could be raised in the future. As a lawyer, whether in legal aid or in private practice, one of the problems that I came across was where people came wanting simple assistance for dissolution of marriage. I think that there should be some assistance provided but I think the Family Court could provide assistance. They insist on things being typed, they insist on the applications and the affidavits being typed and in a proper form. If the Family Court registry actually sat down and devised a simple, plain English form which people could fill in, we would have a system for access to dissolution of marriage which would be more equitable. I cannot emphasise more the need, as has been highlighted in the report, for counselling services. As a legal aid lawyer, and in private practice, quite often people would come to me seeking legal advice when what they really needed was financial counselling. They had debts and they had the debt collector knocking on their door. They needed someone to sit down with them, go through their accounts, give them advice-not legal advice-and get them out of the system. There is even provision in my electorate for that but I think we have to do more than that. It is important that we fund cases of national importance. It is important that any system fund test cases. It is also important, as I said before, that we fund the Environmental Defender's Office. But, if we do that, we have also got to reform the law of standing. It is not good and it is a particular problem in Queensland if we give people or community groups legal access to courts. If they are required to put up litigation bonds to take action against powerful forces in society, that effectively prohibits them from access to justice, and that is something the states will have to look at. (Time expired) non-lawyer who has spoken so far on this debate. I do so in the context of genuinely believing that this is not one of those debates where one is just going through the motions for party purposes and pushing a line that one does not really agree with. In contrast to the member for Wide Bay( Mr Truss), I actually think this is more than a grand gesture, more than hyperbole. I actually think there are some very valuable initiatives in this action by the government. One of the few areas I want to talk about that does not really concern my electorate is the issue of interpreters-particularly with regard to the Aboriginal community. In the Australian Institute of Criminology'S 'Trends and issues No. 47', John Walker and David Macdonald again refer to the high incarceration of Aboriginals-constituting, as they do, 14 per cent of the prison population. They, of course, went through the usual realities: Aboriginals are three
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Ferguson (Reid) (12.46 P.m.)
theText: I think that on the government side I am the onlyWednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 345 times more likely to be unemployed, 2V2 times more likely to be in rental accommodation and 14 times more likely to reside in what are termed 'improvised dwellings'. That again interrelates with the question of whether they will get bail, et cetera, and their incarceration. They also said that, in addition, linguistic difficulties in some parts of Australia would make it difficult for indigenous suspects to communicate their situation to police. I guess we are quite aware that that also occurs in the court system. In the Northern Territory, Western Australia and some other areas, there can be no doubt that many Aboriginals are in gaol simply for want of an interpreter. We run around -he place talking about other NESB groups, but I think this issue has been neglected. I am pleased that the government has done something about this initiative. The overall thrust of the $160 million, which is not a meagre figure over four years, is-if anything-to limit the need to go through the court system and, in periods of anguish, worry, concern and stress, to try going towards mediation or other alternatives in some areas. It is also about simplifying the system and giving more access to information for people-if they have to go to court-to ensure that they have more knowledge. Equally, in the federal sphere at least, it is about requiring lawyers to give more information with regard to costs and alternative methods of reducing those costs. There is a big thrust in the overall proposal with regard to family services, domestic violence and community legal centres. There is also the issue of training for court personnel and judges to make them more aware of the changing nature of this country. There has also been a fairly strong effort on a diverse range of events. The member for Melbourne ( Mr Tanner) alluded to his attitudes on gun laws. I put on the record my strong position on this issue. In fact, in my 1984 maiden speech in the New South Wales parliament, I concentrated on this issue. I am pleased to see that, in this particular overall Justice Report, the government is moving towards further restrictions on the importation of machine guns. The government also notes that it will seek that all territories and states tighten gun licensing requirements and that gun registration is introduced in those states and territories where it does not exist. We are going to find that some individuals will manage to carry out offences despite all the registration requirements in the world. We know that criminal elements can obtain guns, whatever the best efforts of the community, but, essentially, this country has started to go down the wrong road already in regard to the increasing number of people in possession of guns. In addition, there is a large number of people with a vested interest in resisting restrictions. Once you give people something, it is very difficult to take it back, and we are slowly drifting down the US cycle. Despite our culture and despite a lot more reticence about guns, unfortunately those first few steps have been climbed and there are more people who feel they have to have guns: they feel threatened; they feel that society is increasingly unsafe and insecure; and they require to be armed. As I say, I am pleased that the government, in a very broad document of about 190 pages, has emphasised that issue and intends to try and do something about it. The document also concentrates on a few areas that matter to my electorate in a very fundamental sense. In my electorate, 29V2 per cent of people over 15 years of age were born overseas-believe it or not-and 13 per cent of the entire electorate have been in this country less than five years. We have a number of initiatives in regard to non-English speaking people: assistance in professional development programs so that Family Court judges, Administrative Appeal Tribunal members, et cetera are aware of cross-cultural aspects; detailed research on MC 346 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 the disadvantages faced by people of non-English speaking background in the justice system and focusing on determining the levels of unmet demand; introduction of reforms in legal aid at a national level to ensure increased access and equity in the legal aid system for people of non-English backgrounds; funding of women's legal centres to develop appropriate forms of assistance for women of non-English speaking backgrounds; and an overall emphasis on financial counselling, marriage guidance and other relationship support agencies. All these initiatives are trying to ensure that people of non-English speaking background have equal access. I have got to say, having lived my whole life in an electorate where there are a number of new arrival cultures, that this is a fundamental problem. It is possible to see women who are, basically, divorced and shipped overseas by their husbands without knowing what day of the week it is. It is a situation where people, because of the language problem, tend to gravitate to a very small circle of solicitors who then have a captive market. I am not saying that this a majority trend, but a minority of these solicitors come to this country with legal qualifications from elsewhere. They are, perhaps, imbued with the culture of these legal systems and the knowledge of how lawyers might operate elsewhere rather than the standards we might prefer in this country. As I say, there is a very great problem in communities in areas such as the inner west of Sydney in regard to people-mainly women-getting access to our court system, knowing their rights and being able to fight for them, and being put into networks of people who can assist them. I see it in a real sense. It is a necessary effort to undertake to change this situation, and this particular document does something about it. It is worth noting the overall expansion of legal aid, and there are a number of proposals for a national network of environmental lawyers. Honourable members are quite aware that, regardless of which party is in government in different states, there have been restrictions on who can undertake very necessary legal action on the environment. This proposal allows more rights to the individual through environmental lawyers. The government is to expand the network of legal services and will establish a natural human rights and discrimination law centre, specialist litigation advocates in a number of existing community legal centres, and also, most importantly, nine new generalist community law centres. I notice that they are in a number of regions where there is obviously a need, and I do not think that people will quibble about the areas. The areas are: the Riverina area between the Victorian and New South Wales borders; the northern part of New South Wales; the central coast; and, close to my electorate, the outer west of Sydney, which is represented by the member for Chifley( Mr Price) and the member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm). There is no doubt that huge housing estates have massive policing problems and socioeconomic characteristics and that the people who live in the estates have a proclivity to be involved in crime. These areas need this kind of community legal aid centre, and I put on the record my support for the government in undertaking the establishment of such a service. There is also another matter that I have been interested in locally. I am aware that, in the last few years, the St Vincent de Paul Society has initiated handover centres for separated couples. The actual process of arranging times and places and the questions of access are very often the source of great friction in those relationships. The St Vincent de Paul Society pioneered a scheme in New South Wales. In this overall Justice Statement, the government has taken those suggestions on board and is spending $5.3 million on prototype centres to see Wednesday, 23 August 1995 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 347 how well they operate. Those centres will have legal workers who are trained in dealing with family violence. That should reduce what is a very traumatic national problem. On the question of a national missing persons bureau, the figures are that in 1993-94 over 27,000 people were reported missing. They were a very diverse range of people-people with mental disabilities, people in stress situations, people with emotional problems, people who were abducted, et cetera. People can knock any kind of overall justice statement, but I think this national missing persons bureau is a worthwhile initiative by the government. The bureau will be part of a national exchange of police information. Over a million dollars is going into it. There will be photographs here and overseas. There will be an emphasis on children who are missing and on foreign nationals who go missing within Australia. Once again, it is worthwhile, the electorate wants it and I am pleased to see it mentioned in the Justice Statement. In this document there are a series of proposals that deal with safety. One of the unfortunate developments in Western political systems over the last few years-and it was fairly obvious in the last state elections in New South Wales when the Labor Party did it, and next time around the Liberal and National parties will probably do it-is the attempt to exploit fears in the electorate about violence. A document by the Australian Institute of Criminology mentions a 1991 survey which asked Australians and people in other Western countries whether they had a feeling of being a bit or very unsafe when alone at night. In Australia the figure was 31 per cent who felt unsafe. That is significantly above that of a number of European countries, with Belgium at 20 per cent, Finland at 18 and Sweden at 14. There is no doubt that there are concerns out there. We know that it is related to people's personal experiences and whether they have been victims in the past. People are also more inclined to be concerned if they are women or older people. WhilstI support the government trying to do something to reassure the electorate, I draw attention to Australian Institute of Criminology document No. 44, by P.N. Grabosky, which says: Overseas researchers have concluded that the effect of newspaper coverage is complex, with some forms of coverage increasing fear and other forms of coverage decreasing fear. The effect of official crime rates on fear is also mediated through the newspaper coverage of crime. In Britain, readers of tabloid newspapers which have more sensational crime coverage reported higher levels of fear than readers of broadsheet newspapers, whose crime coverage is less predominant and less dramatic. This applies to the political system as well. There is no doubt we can increase the fears of people, we can make them more inclined to support harsh regimes in prisons, and more inclined to demand that extreme measures be taken, but there is a public responsibility. The things that the government is suggesting in this scheme are worthwhile, but on the way through I must express concern about the developments in the political system in this country, and also in the media, that are leading to unnecessary, exaggerated fears within the population. Contingency fees are another matter that the government attempts to move on in this document, with $10Y2 million for national disbursements essentially saying that, yes, it is a good idea to try to explore the possibilities of no-win, no-payment litigation. But there are initial, up-front fees that people often cannot pay, so this Justice Statement provides that money so that we can at least see how it will operate. Payments will only have to be made if the client wins. MC 348 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 23 August 1995 There are also proposals for a specialist women's legal centre. I am pleased to say that, as a state member of parliament, I had an involvement with the housing department in gaining premises for the women's legal centre in my own electorate. I am quite aware that, once it was established, it provided a useful part of the network-Immigrant Women's Speakout and other groups, and the Workers Health Centre-that provides a service for women. There is no doubt that these centres are necessary, that women have confidence in people of the same gender who are giving the advice. These will provide referral to other agencies, some advocacy and some representation, as well as giving a broad range of advice and information. In conclusion, I strongly support the document. I think it is a worthwhile initiative and I hope that the government is a bit more active in publicising it. Debate (on motion by Mr Neb) adjourned.
